c74object.name: bach.flat
c74object.digest: Decrease the depth of an llll
c74object.description: Decreases the depth of an llll by eliminating couple of parentheses.

objarg.name: levels
objarg.description: If only one argument is present, it is considered maxlevels. If two arguments are present, they are considered minlevels and maxlevels.

method.name: bang
method.description: Reduce the depth of the most recently received llll

method.name: llll
method.description: The depth of the llll is reduced by removing couple of parentheses, according to the minlevel and maxlevel attributes.

attribute.name: maxlevel
attribute.description: The maxlevel attribute indicates the deepest level of parentheses to remove. Every parenthesis deeper than maxlevel is left alone. For example, maxlevel 1 means "the last level of parentheses to remove is the outermost", maxlevel 2 means "the last level to remove is the second-outermost". If set to a negative number, the levels are counted from the innermost level: maxlevel -1 means "the last level of parentheses to remove is the innermost", that is "remove all the parentheses, down to the deepest"; maxlevel -2 means "the last level to remove is the second-innermost", that is, "always leave the deepest level of parentheses for every branch of the llll". Defaults to -1.

attribute.name: minlevel
attribute.description: The minlevel attribute indicates the less deep level of parentheses to remove. Every parenthesis less deep than maxlevel is left alone. For example, minlevel 1 means "start removing the parentheses from the first level", that is "remove all the parentheses, from the outermost". minlevel 2 means "leave the first level of parentheses alone, and start removing from the second outermost". If set to a negative number, the levels are counted from the innermost level: minlevel -1 means "the first level of parentheses to remove is the innermost", that is "remove only the innermost level"; maxlevel -2 means "remove the two innermost levels", Defaults to 1.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the followings:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.
